ProdigyUpdated on 02 Apr 2019Firstly, it is important to know that if we do nothing, inflation still hits us at around 2.2-2.6% and our value of money depreciates over time.Savings generally wont hit this high, perhaps some higher savings acct at 2-2.2%, or ssb at 2.16%. MasterAnswered on 03 Apr 2019Hi there!Both Zann and Jensen brought up really good pointers on inflation, savings and growing your wealth. Let me add on a couple of others to hopefully get you to see the light on investinga. Diversifying income streamsMany simply rely on one major income stream to fund our expenses etc. However, sometimes we don't see the 'what if's' because in this case, if one loses their job, that sole income stream will be gone too. Therefore, investing will allow one to have passive income which in turn reduces one's financial burden should one income stream be suddenly taken away. b. No one got rich working a 9 - 5 jobWell, truth be told, we all want to get rich (probably gonna be shot by many as rich differs for all) but we all do want to get the things we need and (if possible) want as well. This adds as an additional booster to supplment our funding into the necessities in life. c. Let your money work for youEveryone has 24 hours in a day and we can only generate a certain amount of money working on a task / role. However, the amount of money your money can generate for you is endless and best of all, it can do it 24/7 even while you're asleep.I hope you see the light in investing. It's never too late and never too early to start investing. Now is always the right time. I invested since I was 18 and have been averaging 7-8% annual returns through REITs and Blue Chip stocks, not the highest, but it's something as opposed to my peers who doesn't.0 comments0
